    Test Model Extremes on Fitted and Forecasted Periods

    test_extremes.Rd

    Extends the analysis from model_extremes by generating forecasts and evaluating model residuals and forecast errors relative to the estimated lower extreme threshold. This helps to assess whether future values fall within the expected range or cross the lower extreme boundary.

    test_extremes(analysis_result, h = 1000)

    Arguments

    analysis_result

    A list object returned by model_extremes, containing the fitted model, lower limit, and related metadata.

    h

    Integer. The forecast horizon, i.e., the number of future observations to predict. Default is 1000.

    Value

    A list containing:

    model

    The fitted model object from analysis_result.

    forecast

    A fable forecast object containing mean forecasts and intervals.

    all_errors

    A tsibble containing both fitted residuals and forecast errors.

    lower_limit

    The estimated lower extreme threshold (inherited from the model analysis).

    full_data

    The complete input dataset used for modeling and testing.

    response

    The response variable name as a character string.

    Details

    The function performs two main tasks:

    • Generates forecasts (h steps ahead) using the fitted model.

    • Combines fitted residuals (from the training window) and forecast errors (from the forecasted window) into a unified time series object for downstream analysis and visualization.

    Forecast errors are computed as the difference between the observed response variable and the forecast mean. Both fitted and forecast errors are combined with labels for easy comparison and plotting.

    Examples

    if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
library(tsibble)
library(fable)

# Assume model_extremes() has been run
result <- model_extremes(
  full_data = mydata,
  typical_start = "2020-01-01",
  typical_end = "2020-03-31",
  response = temperature
)

test_result <- test_extremes(result, h = 200)

test_result$all_errors
} # }
